Introduction

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of autosomal recessive disorders in which melanin synthesis and/or distribution is impaired, resulting in changes in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Pathogenesis



Melanin is a brown-black pigment that absorbs ultraviolet radiation to protect the skin and eyes.  Melanocytes synthesize melanin within specialized organelles (ie, melanosomes) and distribute it to other cells in the skin, hair, and eyes through a series of steps, as follows (

figure 1
):



  • Fibrils create a scaffold within the premelanosome to bind and concentrate melanin.
  • Endosomes transport enzymes (eg, tyrosinase) from the Golgi apparatus to the premelanosome.  Tyrosinase catalyzes the first step in melanin synthesis (ie, oxidation of tyrosine to dopamine), marking the transition from a premelanosome to a melanized melanosome (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Melanized melanosomes are distributed to neighboring keratinocytes, where they are arranged around the cell nucleus to protect its DNA from ultraviolet radiation.


Although several mutations can result in the OCA phenotype, the most common mutations involve the gene that encodes tyrosinase.  These mutations result in decreased or absent tyrosinase activity and therefore impaired melanin synthesis, despite a normal number of melanocytes.  This lack of pigment results in the characteristic white or light-colored hair, skin, and irides seen in OCA.



In addition to pigmentation, melanin is involved in the embryologic development of ocular structures.  Without melanin, abnormal optic nerve fiber and foveal development can lead to reduced visual acuity, strabismus (ocular misalignment) (

figure 3
), and/or nystagmus.



OCA is an autosomal recessive disorder that demonstrates locus heterogeneity (ie, mutations at different genetic loci can result in similar phenotypes).  Parents with similar phenotypes can each be homozygous for a recessive mutation on a different chromosome.  Their offspring inherit a mutant allele on a different chromosome from each parent, resulting in a compound heterozygous genotype (

figure 4
).  Because offspring inherit a normal dominant allele from the other parent, the OCA phenotype is not expressed.  Despite this complexity, a family history of disease remains the most significant risk factor for OCA.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation varies depending on the underlying genetic mutation.  For each genotype, the associated phenotype is expressed as a spectrum that ranges from mild to severe, as follows:



  • Cutaneous findings:  Include white or light-colored skin that is susceptible to ultraviolet radiation (eg, sunburn) and therefore at increased risk for skin cancers (eg, squamous cell carcinoma).  Hair, including the brows and lashes (
    image 1
    ), is typically white or light colored.


  • Ocular findings:  Include light-colored irides.  When light shines on the eye (eg, slit-lamp examination, flash photography), it transmits easily through the iris and reflects off the retina, resulting in a characteristic diffuse red reflex (
    figure 5
    ).  Because the translucent irides allow excess light to pass through, patients often have photophobia.  Other common findings include reduced visual acuity, strabismus, nystagmus, and foveal hypoplasia on funduscopic examination.


These findings are often best appreciated when comparing the patient's appearance to that of parents and siblings.

Diagnosis



OCA is a clinical diagnosis based on cutaneous, hair, and ocular findings.  All patients with suspected OCA should receive a comprehensive ophthalmic examination.  In addition, genetic testing to identify the underlying genetic mutation may be necessary in some cases (eg, for reproductive planning).

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for OCA includes other conditions characterized by skin, hair, and/or eye hypopigmentation or depigmentation, including:



  • Vitiligo:  Vitiligo is characterized by acquired patches of depigmentation due to CD8+ lymphocyte-mediated melanocyte apoptosis (
    image 2
    ).
  • ChÃ©diak-Higashi syndrome:  In addition to OCA, ChÃ©diak-Higashi syndrome is characterized by immunodeficiency and platelet dysfunction due to impaired lysosomal trafficking that disrupts melanin uptake by keratinocytes.
  • Waardenburg syndrome and piebaldism (ie, partial albinism):  These conditions are characterized by congenital patches of depigmentation due to defects in melanocyte proliferation and migration.

Management



Management of cutaneous and ocular findings in OCA includes:



  • Cutaneous:  Findings require strict avoidance of sun exposure, as well as use of protective clothing (eg, wide-brimmed hats) and sunscreen with a sun protection factor of at least 30.  Skin cancer surveillance involves comprehensive skin examinations every 6-12 months beginning in adolescence.
  • Ocular:  Findings require the use of corrective lenses.  Tinted lenses may be necessary to relieve photophobia.  In some cases, surgical correction of strabismus may be required.

Prognosis



The prognosis is generally favorable, although there is an increased risk of mortality due to skin cancer, especially for those with limited access to sun protection and skin cancer screening.  Visual impairment and psychosocial challenges regarding appearance can significantly impact quality of life for some and may require counseling.

Summary



Oculocutaneous albinism is a group of rare autosomal recessive disorders characterized by impaired melanin synthesis and/or distribution in the skin, hair, and eyes (
